hr.fer.zemris.java.webserver

Class RequestContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • hr.fer.zemris.java.webserver.RequestContext

  • public class RequestContext
extends java.lang.Object
    RequestContext holds context for executing smart scripts. It also generates a HTML header before the result is written.
    Constructor expects the OutputStream for writing, Map for each parameter type and a List of cookies, which are modeled by the RequestContext.RCCookie class.
    Header properties are set to default values and can be changed with various setter methods.
    Two methods for writing data are available: write(byte[]) and write(String), and before anything is written header is generated and written.
    Author:
    Dan

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  RequestContext.RCCookie
      This class models one cookie used by RequestContext class.

      • RequestContext

        public RequestContext(java.io.OutputStream outputStream,
                      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parameters,
                      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> persistentParameters,
                      java.util.List<RequestContext.RCCookie> outputCookies)
        Creates a new RequestContext with given parameters and default header values.
        Parameters:
        outputStream - OutputStream for writing header and data; cannot be null
        parameters - read-only Map with parameters
        persistentParameters - Map with persistent parameters
        outputCookies - List with cookies

      • write

        public RequestContext write(byte[] data)
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Writes the given data to the OutputStream given in the constructor. If the header wasn't already generated, than the header is written first.
        Parameters:
        data - bytes to write
        Returns:
        this RequestContext object
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • write

        public RequestContext write(java.lang.String text)
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Writes the given data, using the last set encoding (or the default one), to the OutputStream given in the constructor. If the header wasn't already generated, than the header is written first.
        Parameters:
        text - String to write
        Returns:
        this RequestContext object
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs
